sect2.title: Set Definitions
sect2.para: A Set Definition Set Definition is defined as any Definition whose expression is a set of values, defined within square brackets square brackets . Constant set Constant set s are created as a set of explicitly declared constant values constant values that must be declared within square brackets, whether that set is defined as a separate definition or simply included in-line in another expression. All the constants must be of the same type.
The elements in any explicitly declared set can also be composed of arbitrary expressions. All the expressions must result in the same type and must be constant expressions.
sect2.programlisting: SetExp := [1,2+3,45,SomeIntegerDefinition,7*3]; // an INTEGER set with 5 elements

Set Definition Set Definition s can also be defined using the SET function SET function (which see). Sets defined this way may be used like any other set.
sect2.programlisting: SetSomeField := SET(SomeFile, SomeField); // a set of SomeField values
sect2.para: Sets can also contain datasets for use with those functions (such as: MERGE, JOIN, MERGEJOIN, or GRAPH) that require sets of datsets as input parameters.
sect2.programlisting: SetDS := [ds1, ds2, ds3]; // a set of datasets

sect2.title:
Set Ordering and Indexing Set Ordering
Indexing
sect2.para: Sets are implicitly ordered and you may index into them to access individual elements. Square brackets are used to specify the element number to access. The first element is number one (1).

String String s (Character Sets Character Sets ) may also be indexed to access individual or multiple contiguous elements within the set of characters (a string is treated as though it were a set of 1-character strings). An element number within square brackets specifies an individual character to extract.

Substrings may be extracted by using two periods to separate the beginning and ending element numbers within the square brackets to specify the substring substring (string slice string slice ) to extract. Either the beginning or ending element number may be omitted to indicate a substring from the beginning to the specified element, or from the specified element through to the end.
sect2.programlisting: MyString := 'ABCDE'; MySubString1 := MyString[2..4]; // MySubString1 is 'BCD' MySubString2 := MyString[ ..4]; // MySubString2 is 'ABCD' MySubString3 := MyString[2.. ]; // MySubString3 is 'BCDE'

sect2.title: Record Set Definitions
sect2.para: The term “Dataset” Dataset in ECL explicitly means a “physical” data file in the supercomputer (on disk or in memory), while the term “Record Set” Record Set indicates any set of records derived from a Dataset (or another Record Set), usually based on some filter condition to limit the result set to a subset of records. Record sets are also created as the return result from one of the built-in functions that return result sets.

sect2.title: Record Set Ordering and Indexing
sect2.para: All Datasets and Record Sets are implicitly ordered and may be indexed to access individual records within the set. Square brackets are used to specify the element number to access, and the first element in any set is number one (1).
Datasets (including child datasets) and Record Sets may use the same method as described above for strings to access individual or multiple contiguous records.
sect2.programlisting: MyRec1 := Person[1]; // first rec in dataset MyRec2 := Person[1..10]; // first ten recs in dataset MyRec4 := Person[2..]; // all recs except the first
sect2.para: Note: ds[1] and ds[1..1] are not the same thing—ds[1..1] is a recordset (may be used in recordset context) while ds[1] is a single row (may be used to reference single fields).
And you can also access individual fields in a specified record with a single index:
sect2.programlisting: MyField := Person[1].per_last_name; // last name in first rec
sect2.para: Indexing a record set with a value that is out of bounds is defined to return a row where all the fields contain blank/zero values. It is often more efficient to index an out of bound value rather than writing code that handles the special case of an out of bounds index value.
For example, the expression:
is simpler as:
sect2.programlisting: ds[1].x //note that this returns 0 if ds contains no records.
